awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Automating Employability Skills Development for Individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorder and Developmental Disabilities
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project seeks to increase the competitive employability of individuals with developmental disabilities. For individuals with developmental disabilities (autism spectrum disorder and other intellectual disabilities) employment disparities are far greater than their non-disabled peers; Approximately 20% of working-age adults supported by state developmental disability agencies are employed in a paid job and only 15% were employed competitively. The proposed project will develop a product for school districts and higher education establishments to address the needs of approximately 8 million intellectually disadvantaged individuals in the United States education system. The implementation of this innovation seeks to impact the rates of employment in this population, resulting in increases in personal income, reduction of poverty levels, and better health outcomes for individuals. 

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project plans to create a scalable software framework which integrates, evaluates, and analyzes data from school districts and higher education programs in order to enable the use of machine learning to improve the relationship between transition intervention methods and employment outcomes. Using this innovation, school districts would be able accurately predetermine an individuals’ ability to successfully perform tasks associated with employment.  Higher education programs which enroll adults with developmental disabilities may then effectively scale and develop an individual’s employability skills. The framework will provide structured data collection, data alignment, and data interlinking for roadmaps which will be implemented into the product, enabling educators and individuals to interact, learning how employability programmatic factors and educator corrective actions contribute to employability skills development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Neurodivergent individuals (e.g., autism) make up 20% of the world’s population and are 8X more likely to be unemployed than their non-neurodivergent peers. Studies estimate 50 – 75% of 5.6 million autistic adults in the U.S. are unemployed or underemployed. As of 2018, only 15% of adults (18+) with intellectual disabilities (e.g., Down syndrome) had a paid job, of that approximately 6.2% had competitive employment. The inability for these populations to obtain competitive employment contributes to poverty, which increases the risk for disability, and poor health conditions by reducing access to health care and community services that can prevent these conditions from becoming worse.

The Individualized Employability Development (IEDev) v1.0 project uses advanced Machine Learning models to automatically identify employability skill gaps and then outputs an individualized employability skill development plan. IEDev v1.0 focuses on developing executive functioning and soft skill related employability skills for neurodivergent individuals, and individuals with intellectual disabilities. In addition, it will develop employability skills for neurotypical individuals (non-neurodivergent) who are underserved & underrepresented due to socioeconomic status, geographic location, ethnic/racial background, or other barriers.

IEDev v1.0 will be applied to effectively meet the skills development needs of large companies, workforce development programs, and Higher Ed programs. Resulting in significant reductions in the cost of employing expensive & highly trained specialists, and improved employment outcomes. Our long-term objective is for IEDev to be capable of automatically developing employability skills for all individuals.

 

Academic Study Accomplishments

  • Assessing Participant Employability Skills - We standardized the approach for assessing study participant employability skills. This approach enabled our Study Team to assess participant skills using a field-tested employability skills assessment (10 Key Tenets Assessment) against a commonly accepted occupational database (O*NET). With this approach we were able to develop employability skills development roadmaps, containing the interventions needed to develop individual participant skills.
  • Identified Key Employability Indicators - We achieved an agreed upon (by K12, Higher Ed, and disability specialist partners) set of Key Employability Indicators for an individual’s ability to perform in an occupation. Accomplishing the selection of the key indicators enabled our team to understand what variables could contribute to an individual’s employability readiness.  It enabled our team to better understand how to successfully align student strengths to job requirements.
  • Evidence-Based Methods of Intervention Delivery Identification & Selection - We analyzed published research to determine a set of 7 evidence-based practices that would effectively deliver employability skills development interventions to study participants.
  • Institutionalization of IEDev v1.0 into Organizations - We developed an approach to institutionalize IEDev v1.0 into large companies to effectively develop neurodivergent individual employability skills at scale and reduce the impact of unexpected challenges (e.g., unexpected issues that can arise during daily activities, which affect an individual’s productivity).

 

Technical Development Accomplishments

We developed the initial IEDev v1.0 machine learning models for automatically accessing individuals for employment (Skills Assessment Model) and developing employability skills for individuals (Skills Development Model). The Skills Assessment Model predicted assessment scores for notional individuals at an 89% accuracy rate and based on these assessment scores, the Skills Development Model mapped the notional individuals to appropriate interventions (instructions and corrective actions) at an 87% accuracy rate.

 

Commercialization Accomplishments

Our team conducted 33 discovery sessions under NSF Beat the Odds Bootcamp, 108 discovery sessions under the NSF I-Corps program, and 28 self-funded discovery sessions. Our interviews included stakeholders across school districts, parent advocates, Higher Ed, state vocational rehabilitation agencies, workforce development programs, and employers. We confirmed that IEDev v1.0 needed to address 5 major pain points related to:  

  1. Lack of data standards and data continuity between the different parts of the employment ecosystem (see figure 1), e.g. school districts, higher ed programs, workforce development programs, and employers,
  2. Lack of ability to scale subject matter expertise,
  3. Heavy educator workloads,
  4. Loss of subject matter expert knowledge, and
  5. Lack of expert guidance.

We currently have a contract with Texas Mutual, a worker’s compensation insurance company where we are using IEDev v0.5 to develop employability skills for neurodivergent interns. We have a contract with EmployBR, a workforce development program where we are using IEDev v0.5 to develop employability skills for underserved and underrepresented.

 

Dissemination Accomplishments

  • School District Educators - conducted presentations and poster sessions to ~25 special education teachers and administrators to inform them on how IEDev can be used to support their work-based learning efforts.
  • Higher Ed Educators - conducted poster sessions to ~150 Higher Ed professionals to describe how IEDev can be used to more effectively develop student employability skills using a standard data collection method.
  • Vocational Rehabilitation Educators - conducted presentations to over 100 vocational rehabilitation professionals which included counselors, direct services providers, and administrators, to inform them on the importance of incorporating a standard approach for analyzing & measuring employability skills development data to improve their ability to effectively develop skills. 

Last Modified: 07/08/2024
Modified by: Jody Mitchell

Image
  • The employment ecosystem includes school districts, Higher Ed, workforce development programs, state vocational rehabilitation agencies, and employers. IEDev enables effective development of skills through a standard method of data collection, sharing, and reporting across the employment ecosystem.
    Directed Analytics
    Copyrighted
    Jody Mitchell
    Employment Ecosystem
